content.body: matrix spaces seem to be getting more stable. should we assign a stable alias to the TC39 space and start publicizing the link?
bakkot: i read through everything, I think it looks good
content.formatted_body: bakkot: i read through everything, I think it looks good

content.body: I have one question: is there a guidance I can follow on return values? https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/2408/commits/b3e00d294a4fb150197bad80f236815a3de5608c
this is also adjusted according to anba's comments https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/2267

yulia: on returns, the guidance is basically, 1) if the return value isn't going to be consumed, use `Return.` rather than `Return *undefined*`, and conversely, and 2) don't bother with `Return.` as the final step in an AO (unless it would otherwise be empty).
content.formatted_body: yulia: on returns, the guidance is basically, 1) if the return value isn't going to be consumed, use Return. rather than Return *undefined*, and conversely, and 2) don't bother with Return. as the final step in an AO (unless it would otherwise be empty).

content.body: we're not 100% consistent with this right now, but we're close, and I'll fix it up in https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/2429 and https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/2397 once TLA is in
bakkot: thanks, and yes, that is dumb
content.formatted_body: bakkot: thanks, and yes, that is dumb

content.body: Thoughts on whether web APIs should use JS SyntaxError for parsing problems? (Specific API is https://github.com/WICG/urlpattern/.) I see the ES spec uses it for BigInt and JSON.parse, in addition to actual syntax errors.
SyntaxError seems like a reasonable choice to me
JS also uses it for RegExp, which seems like the nearest cousin here
as a bonus, it makes it marginally less awkward to move it into the JS spec if there is ever reason to do so
